Over the past week, as tensions mount over the murder of George Floyd at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer and 25 major metropolitan areas across the...
text:
Politicians' selective outrage

In the weeks leading up to Memorial Day weekend, State Sen. Declan O'Scanlon
and Monmouth County Freeholder Gerry Scharfenberger, released statements and
showed up at "rallies" to reopen the state and restart the economy that had
been put under lockdown by Gov. Phil Murphy.

In fact, Mr. O'Scanlon even encouraged people to break the law. Murphy's
choice to grind New Jersey to a halt in mid-March was to ensure the flattening
of the COVID-19 curve and to not only protect the most vulnerable of our
residents, but to also keep our health care system from being overwhelmed by a
deluge of cases.

Over the past week, as tensions mount over the murder of George Floyd at the
hands of a Minneapolis police officer and 25 major metropolitan areas across
the nation hold public protests demanding action, neither of these elected
officials has released as intense a statement as they did when they stood with
small business owners.

Where is the outrage about the president idly throwing around militaristic
rhetoric and threats toward American citizens who are exercising their First
Amendment rights, largely peacefully and within the rules of the system?

Where is that bold, American spirit these men touted to protect the freedoms
of business owners? A questioning of the most powerful Republican by other,
elected Republicans would go a long way - much longer than my personal,
progressive criticism would ever get.

Some cops are defusing the anger

How nice it is to see police officers standing, marching and kneeling in
solidarity with those protesting the killing of George Floyd.

Where this is being done, we witness stellar examples of chiefs, departments
and individual officers who recognize that they are vital members of the
community and that in breaking down the barriers between themselves and the
people they serve they defuse anger, strengthen their mission and help heal
the divisions that have been allowed to separate us.

Who'd have ever thought that just four years after Colin Kaepernick was
unjustly vilified for his peaceful, dignified protest we'd see police officers
taking a knee?

What a tonic for these troubled times!

title: Politicians' selective outrage
html:
Politicians' selective outrage

In the weeks leading up to Memorial Day weekend, State Sen. Declan O'Scanlon and Monmouth County Freeholder Gerry Scharfenberger, released statements and showed up at "rallies" to reopen the state and restart the economy that had been put under lockdown by Gov. Phil Murphy.

In fact, Mr. O'Scanlon even encouraged people to break the law. Murphy's choice to grind New Jersey to a halt in mid-March was to ensure the flattening of the COVID-19 curve and to not only protect the most vulnerable of our residents, but to also keep our health care system from being overwhelmed by a deluge of cases.

Over the past week, as tensions mount over the murder of George Floyd at the hands of a Minneapolis police officer and 25 major metropolitan areas across the nation hold public protests demanding action, neither of these elected officials has released as intense a statement as they did when they stood with small business owners.

Where is the outrage about the president idly throwing around militaristic rhetoric and threats toward American citizens who are exercising their First Amendment rights, largely peacefully and within the rules of the system?

Where is that bold, American spirit these men touted to protect the freedoms of business owners? A questioning of the most powerful Republican by other, elected Republicans would go a long way - much longer than my personal, progressive criticism would ever get.

Some cops are defusing the anger

How nice it is to see police officers standing, marching and kneeling in solidarity with those protesting the killing of George Floyd.

Where this is being done, we witness stellar examples of chiefs, departments and individual officers who recognize that they are vital members of the community and that in breaking down the barriers between themselves and the people they serve they defuse anger, strengthen their mission and help heal the divisions that have been allowed to separate us.

Who'd have ever thought that just four years after Colin Kaepernick was unjustly vilified for his peaceful, dignified protest we'd see police officers taking a knee?

What a tonic for these troubled times!
